importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred on October 19, 2025, and was reported as happening early Monday, marking a significant aviation safety event at one of the world's busiest airports.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The aircraft skidded off the runway at approximately 3:50 a.m. local time, which is the key operational moment in the incident timeline.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) and crashed into the sea, killing two airport staff in a vehicle it struck.
The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon impact, with its tail section snapped off and the front section severely damaged.
The four crew members onboard were treated for injuries but are confirmed safe; no cargo was on board.
The aircraft did not send distress signals during approach, indicating a possible failure in control or landing procedure.
The airport suspended operations on the north runway but continued operations on two other runways, with no major disruption to over 1,000 daily flights.
The flight was operated under an Emirates flight number but wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides cargo capacity to major airlines.

Hong Kong International Airport has a strong safety record, with rare fatal aviation accidents, though a 1999 crash involving a China Airlines flight landing upside down during a typhoon remains a notable historical event.
The incident prompted a large emergency response involving over 200 people, fire engines, and boats.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Boeing cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) early Monday, October 19, 2025, after landing from Dubai. The aircraft broke in two upon impact and struck an airport security patrol car, killing two occupants. The four crew members were treated for injuries but are confirmed safe, and no cargo was on board. The incident occurred without any distress signals from the pilots, prompting emergency response efforts involving over 200 personnel, fire engines, and boats. The airport suspended operations on the north runway, but operations on two other runways ensured minimal disruption to over 1,000 daily flights. While HKIA has a strong safety record, the event underscores risks even at one of the world’s busiest and most advanced airports, especially when considering past incidents like the 1999 China Airlines crash during a typhoon and the historical difficulty of landing at the former Kai Tak Airport.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
